messages: 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (05:47): would be fine with sql if there were general agreement upon some rigorous specification of exact syntax and behavior
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (05:48): which doesn't seem likely to happen given the enormity of the prerequisite tasks, but is not entirely unlikely

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:09): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: well, a lot of the arguments sicking makes seem to apply equally to ignoring mozilla's preference and requiring support for the sql database api
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:12): The arguments seem completely different to me
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:13): in each case, the argument for inclusion would be to promote interoperability by exerting market pressure on holdouts
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:13): but the reasons for people holding out are completely different
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:14): so your Mozilla's reasons for holding out are valid but Apple's are not?
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:14): Modulo my limited understanding of Apple's reasons --- yes.
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:16): if Web SQL was the only plausible solution for structured client-side storage, I'm sure we'd just bite the bullet and do it.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:20): so existence of plausible (though not yet materialized) alternatives justifies holding out, in a way that specs should accomodate?
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:21): depends on what you mean by "materialized"
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:21): http://hg.toolness.com/browser-couch/raw-file/blog-post/index.html
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:22): there are many other differences between the two situations
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:22): fundamentally, i don't think i should be in the business of saying that apple's reasons are less good than mozilla's reasons
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:22): in particular, not when it won't make any difference anyway
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:22): as in this case

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:23): e.g., only one browser implements Web SQL currently, so there's no interop to speak of, whereas we have three browsers with demoed or shipping Theora implementations, one of which is actually different code
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:23): there's the issue of Web SQL not having a real spec
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:23): Right now we have 1 browser shipping it and 2 that have publicly committed to doing so
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:23): Has Opera committed to it?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:23): vs for Theora, 2 browsers shipping and 1 publicly committed
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:24): Opera has said they will do it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:24): (websql will have a real spec after html5 is in last call, assuming no better alternatives surface -- i'll write it myself if i have to :-) )
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:24): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: OK, that strengthens the case for Web SQL a bit.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:25): I think Mozilla is entitled to wait and see what happens, even if I would prefer you did implement Web SQL
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:25): that's why I proposed splitting it from the rest of the Web Storage spec
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:25): I doubt we'll see an independent implementation of SQLite's SQL dialect, though, which remains a worry
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:25): i think mozilla's concerns with websql are perfectly valid
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:25): i think apple's concerns with theora are valid too
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:26): insofar as mozilla thinks their concerns are valid, and apple thinks their concerns are valid
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:26): fwiw Apple is doing a new round of research on the matter
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:26): I don't think we should shy away from making value judgements about peoples' concerns
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:26): people have unreasonable concerns sometimes
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:26): I know it can sound arrogant
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:26): that's a very dangerous path to go down, imho
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:27): and not one that leads to productive cooperation
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:27): what would you do if i said that mozilla's concerns re websql weren't valid?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:27): i doubt you would really appreciate it
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:27): We'd argue about it
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:27): in the past I've had a lot of concerns that you have assuaged in one way or another
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:28): I don't think I personally, or Mozilla in general, am immune to unrealistic or overblown concerns
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:29): putting them on an untouchable pedestal is itself dangerous
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:29): i'm talking specifically about "we won't implement X" feedback
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:29): for more nuanced feedback, things are more complex

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:29): I think the only thing anyone has done to assuage Apple's concerns (or Google's) about Theora is to say they shouldn't count or imply that they are not on the level
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:29): Mozilla has not said "we won't implement SQL"
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:30): at least, I don't think we have
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:30): not quite as explicitly as apple has said it about theora, i'll grant you

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:31): anyway, my point was just that sicking's comments seemed to be dangerously close to saying "ignore apple", which i don't think it would be appropriate for me to do, as i think it would set a precedent for ignoring any vendor whose feedback isn't convenient.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:31): which could be mozilla, e.g. as with websql
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:32): i'm just trying to treat everyone fairly :-)

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:32): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: there's an interesting thing. Google's got concerns about Theora not being a great codec. Fine. But they're implementing it anyway. I don't understand why Apple can't do the same.
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:32): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: or at least, patents are the only reason I can understand.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:32): our concerns are that we could get sued, and that it might not be viable on the phone
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:32): we're going to investigate both these issues much more in depth
ac3ddd1ee072788599320d47ecd93672 (06:33): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427, btw, here's the message from MS on SQL dialects:
ac3ddd1ee072788599320d47ecd93672 (06:33): http://groups.google.com/group/mozilla.community.web-standards/msg/d6a92db27bd52bcb
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:33): "viable" as in "consumes more power than your H.264 hardware decoder" or as in "Will Not Work At All"?
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:33): the former is a red herring, I think.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:34): I wouldn't phrase it in as absolute a way as you just did
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:34): the latter would be a shock
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (06:35): vlc plays theora videos on jailbroken iphones so it's certainly possible
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:35): One question in the mega-thread that I asked that never got answered is "how would supporting Theora make the iPhone *worse*"?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:35): "viable" as in "consumes more power than seems reasonable" and "renders at adequate performance relative to the quality of experience we expect on iPhone OS"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:36): I phrased one of those backwards
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:36): does Apple reject applications from the iPhone store because they run the CPU at 100%?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:36): "doesn't consume more power than seems reasonable"
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:36): does Safari refuse to render Web pages that run too much JS?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:36): we do limit background apps in part to avoid killing the battery
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:36): and yes, MobileSafari has a JS execution limit
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:36): what sort of limit?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:37): run JS for too long within a given time period and it gets shut off for that page
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:38): I wonder what Opera thinks about this mobile power issue
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:38): since that's most of their business
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:38): anyway, to clarify the parameters, if it took 10x as much battery that would probably be unacceptable, if it took 1.5x, that probably wouldn't be
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (06:38): the camera app on the iphone consumes an enormous amount of power - so does skype. Ban them imho.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:39): anyway I think it needs to be put to the test whether a software-only implementation could be acceptable
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (06:40): I suspect Opera cares less, because it's the device vendor, not the app vendor, who faces the users' ire over poor battery life
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:41): I suspect device vendors are able to forward that feedback
ac3ddd1ee072788599320d47ecd93672 (06:42): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427, anyway, I think the SQL comparison is not such a good. I don't think the storage draft has a dangling dependency.
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:42): ac3ddd1ee072788599320d47ecd93672: it's worse, it has a dependency on something that doesn't exist, a spec for SQLite
ac3ddd1ee072788599320d47ecd93672 (06:42): well, if the storage draft contains SQL
ac3ddd1ee072788599320d47ecd93672 (06:43): if it's moved into a new Web SQL API draft, that document still has it
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:43): right, that could be fixed. I believe Ian when he says he'll fix it if necessary. But we can't be blamed for pushing back against the draft that exists today
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (06:44): no-one really knows how hard it will be to spec out the SQL bit. I have faith in Ian's supreme speccing skills, that's all
ac3ddd1ee072788599320d47ecd93672 (06:44): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427, I read the response as saying the splitting of the storage spec was due to our lack of implementation
ac3ddd1ee072788599320d47ecd93672 (06:44): but it seems to me that splitting the spec is not really the same as leaving something unspecified
